discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The CompTia A+ Study Guide says:
DisplayPort was designed to replace VGA and DVI. To help ease the transition, itâ€™s backward compatible with both standards, using an adapter.
I just know that Display Port can daisy chain.

Selected Answer: B
VGA is always analogous and Displayport is always digital. They are two different types of signals. For me the best reside in the (b)

comments.content:
It says he want two EXTERNAL monitors though. 
I hate these kind of questions, like if you don't know the obvious answer you wouldn't easily figure it out IRL.

discussion.content:
Very very tricky. 

user only wants to have two screens with analog monitors. the first screen looks like it is the laptop itself. Since it has both a vga and and display port connector, we know that the end of the extension cable has to be VGA.

C. a display port to VGA adaptor

This answer is the only one that fits the description of having a either a VGA or display port as computer end and a VGA connection on the other end.

the user already has 1 VGA port, so he needs a DP to VGA for his secondary output. Since the question mentions Analog it has to be VGA. D using a splitter box would only clone his screen and not use it as dual monitors.

The question makes mention of analog monitors being used for the connection, so a VGA converter would mostly solve the issue.
VGA is an analog interface.
It doesn't make sense
How is this not D??????
Shouldn't this one be D? A DP to VGA adapter will only provide one Dsub connector not 2 as needed.

comments.content: Remember, he already has one VGA connector.

questions.question_text: A user purchased a new laptop that has a built-in display, VGA connector, and DisplayPort connector. When working at the office, the user only wants an extended desktop to display on two external analog monitors. Which of the following is required?

A developer reports a recurring computer issue while compiling a program. The computer works at first, but it locks up during the compilation process. An immediate reboot does not resolve the issue. Which of the following procedures will MOST likely solve the problem?

choices.D: Decrease the number of memory modules.

discussion.content: Yep it makes no sense whatsoever
This answer is confusing. CPUs are designed to shut down when overheating, rather than freezing.
I guess out of all the options, overheating is most likely so need to reapply thermal paste. I was thinking need more RAM...
It looks like an overheating problem, so applying new high quality thermal paste might help.

comments.content: depends on manufacturer, but usually when temperature reach a value, example 90 C degree, computers will start responding slowly or even hang up. when reach higher temperature than that, example 100 C degree it will instantly shutdown
Why does it look like a overheating problem?

questions.question_text:
While troubleshooting a magnetic hard drive, a technician hears a loud clicking noise, identifies S.M.A.R.T. errors, and notices the operating system will not load.
Which of the following is MOST likely the issue?

choices.A: The cooling fans are faulty, causing overheating.

discussion.content: The S.M.A.R.T. system allows the user to give full information about the physical status of the hard disk using the estimation method, which can be used to calculate the approximate time before an HDD failure.

The question is testing the significance of clicking noises in combination with S.M.A.R.T. errors, which would most likely indicate an imminent hard drive failure. Answer B is the only choice that pertains to hard drives.

comments.content: I think i didnt read the question properly, IF it was a overheating problem then the OS would boot then crash somewhere along.
True, it was clear on there that the OS wasn't loading.

discussion.content:
I tried my best to understand but i cant choose if its A or B.
Did some searches and found out that the common cause of a SMART error is Temperature problem or hard drives have high average temperature. 
On the other hand the source did say that SMART is a tool that lets you know that a drive will fail beforehand. 
Source: https://www.seagate.com/ca/en/support/kb/my-system-reported-a-smart-error-on-the-drive-184619en/

comments.content: some people call it either or, but COMPTIA should of kept it simple and left it as IaaS

discussion.content: IAAS not HAAS

Never heard it called HaaS. Like it hasn't been challenging enough for though of us new to this to learn this material. Why does CompTIA feel compelled to use confusing and misleading content? This is so dumb. ðŸ˜

Following the elimination strategy one can strike answers B (question does not pertain to development), C (SaaS provides off-the-shelf software solutions and end user would not have control of the environment), and D (question does not pertain to combination of on-premises and cloud data storage). The only remaining answer is A.

questions.question_text:
A technician needs to build a cloud solution with the following parameters:
âœ‘ Predictable cost
âœ‘ Easy expansion of resources
âœ‘ Ability to control every aspect of the environment
Which of the following would be the BEST solution for the technician to implement?

discussion.content: Plenum cable is electrical cable that is laid in the plenum spaces of buildings. In the United States, plastics used in the construction of plenum cable are regulated under the National Fire Protection Association standard NFPA 90A: Standard for the Installation of Air Conditioning and Ventilating Systems.

questions.question_text: A technician needs to select and install network cabling in an office ceiling. The technician was told the space above the ceiling is part of the air conditioning return system. Which of the following cable features is MOST likely to be a safety requirement?
